data.title: 50 Best Italian Movies Of All Time
data.meta_description: The greatest Italian films of all time: from ‚ÄòBicycle Thieves‚Äô to ‚ÄòThe Great Beauty‚Äô
data.text:
There‚Äôs a reason Martin Scorsese has dedicated part of his life to championing Italian movies ‚Äì and it‚Äôs not just to keep his nonna happy. It‚Äôs the national cinema that gave us Fellini, Visconti, Rossellini, Pasolini, and De Sica ‚Äì where one minute you can corpse to the slapstick silliness of Commedia all'Italiana capers and the next, have your heart smashed into tiny pieces by a human drama about an old man and his dog. Where dodgy politics spawns angry thrillers and seismic historical events are tackled in sweeping epics. And where Clint Eastwood chewed on a cheroot while dispatching bad guys, and Argento and Bava gave us the lurid shocks of giallo. It‚Äôs flamboyant, glamorous, jaded, shocking and sexy ‚Äì sometimes all at once.

And it‚Äôs not just sexy people standing in fountains, either. Rome‚Äôs famous old Cinecitt√† Studios powers on, the Venice Biennale is the world‚Äôs coolest film festival (sorry, Cannes), and modern-day moviemakers like Alice Rohrwacher, Matteo Garrone, Paolo Sorrentino and Gianfranco Rosi keep offering up fresh slices of la dolce vita (or its darker sides). With the BFI celebrating the work of the Taviani brothers in February and neorealism in May-June, a ‚ÄòCinema Made in Italy‚Äô season running at London‚Äôs Cin√© Lumi√®re in March, Rohrwacher‚Äôs La Chimera and Garrone‚Äôs Oscar-nominated Io Capitano coming to cinemas soon, not to mention a cinema re-release of Rome, Open City in May. There‚Äôs plenty of Italian films to sample out there. Allow us to add 50 more to the list ‚Äì the best of the lot.

1. 8¬Ω (1963)

Director: Federico Fellini

By the early ‚Äô60s, Federico Fellini had fully abandoned neorealism in favour of more symbolic, emotional and thematically complex filmmaking. His flights of fancy had grown increasingly fancier and flightier, reaching their peak with 8¬Ω, a kind of ‚Äòpsychological autobiography‚Äô about a director in the throes of artistic inertia. Marcello Mastroianni is Fellini‚Äôs avatar, a filmmaker who can‚Äôt seem to make a movie and prefers to retreat into his own head, revelling in memories and fantasies while battling his own creative anxiety. The irony, of course, is that Fellini was more than capable of making a movie. And this is his most definitive.‚ÄîMatthew Singer

Director: Bernardo Bertolucci

Bertolucci‚Äôs towering examination of one young, ambitious right-wing thug ‚Äì played by Jean-Louis Trintignant with blank malice ‚Äì may be his finest film. Set during the Mussolini regime, and employing some of the most gorgeous art deco mise-en-sc√®ne imaginable, Bertolucci uses the baroque style of the 1930s to convey ‚Äì and undermine ‚Äì the spirit of fascism. As Trintignant‚Äôs troubled antihero prepares to carry out an assassination attempt on a former professor, the loss of his soul becomes painfully clear. The film‚Äôs legendary cinematographer Vittorio Storaro would go on to work with Francis Ford Coppola ‚Äì in part because of Coppola‚Äôs love for this film.‚ÄîChristina Newland

Advertising

Director: Roberto Rossellini

One of films most closely associated with Italian neorealism, Rome, Open City is a film-school staple ‚Äì and for good reason. Filmed in the crumbling ruins of the city in the aftermath of World War II, Rossellini synthesised his experiences, and those of his friends, into a complex story of Romans under Nazi occupation. The phenomenal Anna Magnani makes the biggest impression. The heartbreaking sequence in which her man is rounded up by Germans and she is caught in the crossfire powerfully drives home the price paid by brave resistance members during the war.‚ÄîChristina Newland

Director: Luchino Visconti

The best-looking film in all of cinema? With its gorgeous colour palette, smokeshow cast (Alain Delon and Claudia Cardinale), glittering ballroom sequence and Risorgimento-era set pieces that spill over with chaotic action, The Leopard would surely be right up there with The Conformist in any People Magazine poll. But its themes of decay and revolution, adapted from Giuseppe Tomasi di Lampedusa‚Äôs novel and embodied in Burt Lancaster‚Äôs ageing aristocrat and Delon as his impetuous nephew, make it a kind of 19th century Succession too. Visconti, the son of Milanese aristocrats who turned to Marxism during the war, knew more about this stuff than most, but he never lets the politics obscure the humanity ‚Äì helped by a Lancaster performance full of sorrowful dignity.‚ÄîPhil de Semlyen

Advertising

Director: Roberto Rossellini

Power couple Roberto Rossellini and Ingrid Bergman‚Äôs finest creative partnership is a key moment in modern cinema. From the somewhat mundane story of Bergman and George Sanders‚Äô crumbling marriage during a trip to Naples, it works through mood and metaphor to ascend from emotional emptiness to spiritual transcendence. Daringly, Rossellini allows much tetchy unease before the ancient landscape's history and traditions gradually impact the seemingly listless central duo. Voyage to Italy is a truly contemporary vision ‚Äì a waymarker for Antonioni and the French New Wave, and a testament to vulnerable togetherness confronting time and mortality.‚ÄîTrevor Johnston

6. Once Upon A Time In The West (1968)

Director: Sergio Leone

Sill the best film with a ‚ÄòOnce Upon a Time in‚Ä¶‚Äô prefix (sorry Midlands, Hollywood), Sergio Leone‚Äôs takes everything you love about his Dollars trilogy ‚Äì big landscapes, bigger close-ups, violence, comedy ‚Äì and adds extra breadth, depth and stature. From its unparalleled title sequence as three hired killers wait the arrival of The Man (Charles Bronson) on a train, it debunks the mythology of the Hollywood Western ‚Äì hero Henry Fonda as a cold killer ‚Äì operating as an operatic eulogy to the genre, enriched by Ennio Morricone‚Äôs ground-breaking score. A strong contender for the greatest Western ever made.‚ÄîIan Freer

Advertising

Director: Francesco Rosi

Francesco Rosi takes on the life of infamous Sicilian bandit in a fascinating story told with typical passion and polemical fire. Using flashbacks and flashforwards, after introducing Giuliano lifeless in a pool of his own blood, Rosi gives us a kaleidoscope of different viewpoints on this ‚Äô50s-folk-hero-turned-public-enemy, refusing to lead the viewer to take sides so much as to probe their own feelings for the bandit‚Äôs deeds. The film isn‚Äôt exactly entry-level in its deep ties to Italian politics and history, but it‚Äôs worth sticking with. And don‚Äôt take my word for it: it‚Äôs one of Martin Scorsese‚Äôs favourite films.‚ÄîChristina Newland

Director: Federico Fellini

How many films have caused fights in the cinema aisles? Legend has it that a brawl broke out when Fellini‚Äôs La Strada premiered at the Venice, which seems extreme for a movie about a circus clown (Fellini muse Giulietta Masina) and her marriage to Anthony Quinn‚Äôs abusive strongman. But this was a seismic moment in the director‚Äôs career, when he moved away from neorealism and toward a surrealist sophistication that would come to be known as ‚ÄòFelliniesque‚Äô. Some critics saw it as a betrayal. Three quarters of a century later, La Strada just feels sublime ‚Äì a melancholy, searching tone poem about the loss of innocence that laid a path for masterpieces to come.‚ÄîMatthew Singer

Advertising

Director: Mario Bava

If only all film debuts were as good as Mario Bava‚Äôs. Black Sunday is an atmospheric gothic horror, released in 1960 and banned in the UK until 1968 for its graphic violence, considered too gruesome at the time. Based very loosely on Nikolai Gogol‚Äôs story ‚ÄòViy‚Äô, the film follows the wrath of the powerful witch-vampire Asa (played by Barbara Steele in one of her first big-screen roles), who places a curse on her family after they execute her for Satanism. And for being a vampire. And a witch. And being too‚Ä¶ horny? Few horrors deliver performances as haunting as Steele‚Äôs in Bava‚Äôs creepy classic.‚ÄîAnna Bogutskaya

10. La Notte (1961)

Director: Michelangelo Antonioni

No one can make a dying relationship seem quite as cinematic as Antonioni. La Notte dresses up Marcello Mastroianni‚Äôs jaded writer and Jeanne Moreau‚Äôs disillusioned wife to the nines and sets them lose on an urbane Milan, where louche soir√©es, existential angst, and a sexily inscrutable Monica Vitti await them. Antonioni‚Äôs existential mood pieces aren‚Äôt for everyone, but these levels of seductive languor are hard to resist. Emotionally sparse but never blank, and with cut-glass black-and-white compositions, it‚Äôs easy to see why La Notte was one of Stanley Kubrick‚Äôs favourite films.‚ÄîPhil de Semlyen

Advertising

Director: Gillo Pontecorvo

Before the invasion of Iraq in 2003, The Pentagon put on a screening of The Battle of Algiers to gain insights into counter-terrorism techniques. It‚Äôs easy to see why. Gillo Pontecorvo‚Äôs film about the struggle for Algerian independence from the French is a clear-eyed how-to of guerrilla warfare, told through a mixture of documentary stylings and Ennio Morricone-scored poetry. Yet what stands out is the even-handedness on display, as Pontecorvo brilliantly explores the perspectives and problems on both sides (Jean Martin‚Äôs French paratroop commander is unforgettable). Paul Greengrass‚Äôs favourite film, it was also shown to the Algerian football team to instil underdog revolutionary zeal before a World Cup match against England. The result was ‚Äì obviously ‚Äì a nil-nil draw.‚ÄîIan Freer

Director: Federico Fellini

Federico Fellini‚Äôs copper-bottomed masterpiece is an odyssey through decadence in seven episodes as gossip columnist Marcello (Marcello Mastroianni) looks to find himself in a morally bankrupt ‚Äô60s Rome. Fellini puts indelible imagery ‚Äì a statue of Christ being flown over Rome, Anita Ekberg wading into the Trevi Fountain ‚Äì at the service of a masterful study of paralysing ennui, the pursuit of misplaced values, and the loss of self. It‚Äôs one of those rare films that gifted the world a word ‚Äì Walter Santesso‚Äôs hyperactive photographer is named ‚ÄòPaparazzo‚Äô ‚Äì but more importantly delivers a rich, unforgettable experience, a film so full it makes most films look anaemic by comparison.‚ÄîIan Freer

Advertising

13. Il Sorpasso (1962)

Director: Dino Risi

No one grumbles about ‚Äòfucking Merlot‚Äô but make no mistake, without this commedia d'italia classic there‚Äôd be no Sideways. In fact, Dino Risi‚Äôs astute and stinging comedy of male inadequacy, not to mention the odd-couple dynamic at its heart, makes Il Sorpasso a blueprint for just about any offbeat road-trip movie. Vittorio Gassman and Jean-Louis Trintignant play a high-living gadabout and the meek law student he takes under his wing. Cue girls, booze, beaches, and all the ingredients for a frisky coming-of-age adventure ‚Äì at least, until it all comes crashing down in an ending that goes off like a hand grenade in a martini glass.‚ÄîPhil de Semlyen

Director: Vittorio De Sica

Vittorio De Sica‚Äôs working-class tragedy is made all the more crushing by its mundanity. The story couldn‚Äôt be simpler: a downtrodden man in postwar Italy finds a job posting advertisements, but his employment is dependent upon owning a bicycle; when his is stolen, he and his young son set out across Rome to find it. One of the most affecting illustrations of the cycle of poverty and crime ever made, it was shot with non-professional actors and achieves the neorealists‚Äô aim of capturing life as it actually happens. In a cruel twist, star Lamberto Maggiorani was laid off from his factory job after the movie‚Äôs release. As his own character says: ‚ÄòYou live and you suffer.‚Äô‚ÄîMatthew Singer

Advertising

15. The Great Silence (1968)

Director: Sergio Corbucci

This desolate, subversive western may be the high-point of Corbucci‚Äôs career thanks to its ice-cold atmosphere and brilliant performances. Klaus Kinski is a scene-stealer in the role of a ruthless bounty killer who believes it‚Äôs his ‚Äòpatriotic duty to exterminate‚Äô outlaws ‚Äì while Jean-Louis Trintignant is quietly compelling as his opponent: a mute avenger who survived a throat-slitting as a child. Silvano Ippoliti‚Äôs alpine cinematography is frequently breathtaking, and would later serve as a key influence on Tarantino‚Äôs The Hateful Eight ‚Äî a film with which it also shares a composer in Ennio Morricone. ‚ÄîJames Balmont

Director: Pier Paolo Pasolini

A huge influence on Martin Scorsese‚Äôs The Last Temptation Of Christ, Pier Paolo Pasolini‚Äôs take on the birth, teachings and death of Christ is the perfect antidote to the bloated Hollywood epics of the ‚Äò50s. Employing techniques from the neorealist movement (Pasolini gets fantastic mileage from the faces of non-professional actors), it takes Christ out of beatific religious representations and puts him into the real world, raw, violent and politically-informed as it is. Unbelievably moving, whatever your faith.‚ÄîIan Freer

Advertising

17. Ossessione (1943)

Director: Luchino Visconti

‚ÄòThe Postman Always Rings Twice‚Äô has been much-adapted but never bettered than in Luchino Visconti‚Äôs unauthorised take on James M Cain‚Äôs pulpy noir. Massimo Girotti is the handsome drifter who catches the eye of Clara Calamai‚Äôs bored tavern landlady, only for the pair‚Äôs affair to go torridly wrong. Somehow, this brilliantly clammy thriller is Visconti‚Äôs first film ‚Äì he was put onto the novel by Jean Renoir while working as the Frenchman‚Äôs assistant director ‚Äì and its real Po Valley locations and gritty, hard-bitten characters paved the way for neorealist flicks to come. Oh, and he made it in the middle of a world war.‚ÄîPhil de Semlyen

Director: Paolo Sorrentino

A modern companion piece to La Dolce Vita updated for the Berlusconi era, Paolo Sorrentino‚Äôs sensory overload sends another jaded journo, Jep Gambardella (Toni Servillo), through the morass of the Eternal City, bobbing from one decadent party to another. From the costumes to his music choices Sorrentino‚Äôs filmmaking is bravura, Luca Bigazzi‚Äôs camera zooming and swooping, adding to the operatic quality of a film that skates on love, loss and, towards the end, a profound melancholy. Emotional emptiness has rarely been this satisfying.‚ÄîIan Freer

Advertising

Director: Dario Argento

An American girl (Jessica Harper) enrols at a prestigious ballet academy in Germany, only to discover something sinister within its walls. It‚Äôs the stuff of fairy tales; indeed, Argento has noted Disney‚Äôs Snow White as an influence. Argento floods the screen with garish primary colours, including sprays of unnaturally red blood, and his grisly set pieces still retain a quality of stained-glass beauty. What elevates Suspiria into the horror pantheon, though, is Italian prog-rockers Goblin‚Äôs shuddering soundtrack. Luca Guadagnino‚Äôs 2018 remake upped the gore, added political subtext, and had Thom Yorke doing the score, but there‚Äôs no improving upon the original.‚ÄîMatthew Singer

20. L‚ÄôAvventura (1960)

Director: Michelangelo Antonioni

Antonioni‚Äôs seminal film of the moneyed classes defined mid-century alienation. He reshuffles the rules of cinema in the process, offering a missing-person mystery where finding the missing person is almost beside the point. At its centre, among the ominous coves and inlets of the Aeolian Islands (40-odd kilometers from where Rossellini filmed Stromboli), a woman vanishes and her elegant best friend (Monica Vitti, in one of her defining roles) tries to find her. Pauline Kael disdainfully referred to it a ‚Äòcome dressed as the sick soul of Europe party‚Äô, but this peculiar and languorously-paced film changed the face of ‚Äô60s cinema.‚ÄîChristina Newland

Advertising

Director: Sergio Leone

Shot in Spain with American stars, sure, but as Italian as a bowl of pasta, this gunslinging classic is peak Sergio Leone. The Roman first two Dollars films are trifles compared to the sweep and slyness of his third entry. The irony of the title, of course, is that all these dudes are bad. It‚Äôs also so much cooler than many of those older films. Clint Eastwood‚Äôs poncho-draped Man With No Name? The close-ups? Ennio Morricone‚Äôs twangy, whistling, operatic score, which is arguably more famous than the movie itself? The climatic cemetery shootout? It‚Äôs a landmark of iconographical radness, admired by the likes of Tarantino and Scorsese, but never quite matched.‚ÄîMatthew Singer

Director: Luchino Visconti

A tapestry of melodrama and social realism, Luchino Visconti‚Äôs beautiful, sweeping tale of the Parondi family is a heartbreaker. The story follows the migration of a mother and her five strapping sons from the South to find work in Milan: Alain Delon, young and angelic, is Rocco, who attempts to curb the worst impulses of his more freewheeling brother Simone (Renato Salvatori) and the neighborhood sex worker (Annie Girardot). Visconti explores the changes in Italian social life at this period of economic prosperity, where the bright lights of the big city offer the potential for ruin.‚ÄîChristina Newland

Advertising

23. Stromboli (1950)

Director: Roberto Rossellini

Rossellini‚Äôs tempestuous drama stares you square in the face and dares you to call it romantic. The filmmaker‚Äôs lover (and then wife, and then ex-wife) Ingrid Bergman plays Karin, a Lithuanian refugee at the end of the war, who ties the knot with a hulking Italian ex-POW (fisherman-turned-thesp Mario Vitale) to escape her internment camp. Back on his Sicilian island, she finds this jagged world of hostile fishermen suffocating and plots to escape. A brooding drama that threatens to explode like the simmering volcano on which it‚Äôs set, it gave Italian cinema one of its most famous endings.‚ÄîPhil de Semlyen

Director: Pietro Germi

This bitumen black comedy has a sky-high concept that modern Hollywood would kill for. An impoverished Sicilian aristocrat (Marcello Mastroianni) plots to kill his wife (Daniela Rocca) by setting her up to have an affair to take advantage of an Italian legal loophole that a wronged husband will get off lightly if he murders his missus (and her lover) in the act. Winner of the Best Screenplay Oscar, it‚Äôs a darkly funny satire that deliciously skewers Sicilian macho mores. And then some.‚ÄîIan Freer

Advertising

25. The Great War (1959)

Director: Mario Monicelli

One of the great First World War movies ‚Äì sadly, tough to track down in English-subtitled form ‚Äì Mario Monicelli‚Äôs masterpiece plays like a kind of ‚ÄòAll Quiet on the Italian Front‚Äô or a tragicomic version of Paths of Glory. It tackles notions of patriotism and duty with a smirk that really rubbed critics up the wrong way when it was first released, before shrugging the controversy off to win a Golden Lion. Nestled within its huge battles scenes (Dino De Laurentiis was its super-producer) and gnarly depictions of trench warfare, it‚Äôs really a buddy movie in which Vittorio Gassman and Alberto Sordi take a Matthieu-and-Lemmon-ish approach to military service: grousing, shirking and cheating, before finally finding their nobility in the face of ruthless Austrian troops.‚ÄîPhil de Semlyen

Director: Alice Rohrwacher

Taking its name from an Italian turn of phrase that loosely translates as ‚Äòhappy as Larry‚Äô, this fable of ‚Äô70s class warfare and friendship in rural (and later, urban) Italy is moving and sharp by turns. An innocent-minded young man, played with dimwit sweetness by Adriano Tardiolo, is a farm labourer working under a near-feudal system. He befriends the wealthy son of the marchioness who runs the estate he works on to poignant ‚Äì and eventually disastrous ‚Äì effect. Showing the negative effects of money and exploitation on ordinary people, Alice Rohrwacher‚Äôs film might be called social commentary were it not so charmingly weird.‚ÄîChristina Newland

Advertising

27. Paisan (1946)

Director: Roberto Rossellini

This stirring World War II anthology movie ‚Äì six vignettes that loosely follow the Allied advance north through Italy ‚Äì combines gritty social realism with straight-up war movie beats that wouldn‚Äôt be out of place in a Hollywood flick. It‚Äôs occasionally uneven but boasts a kind of incremental power that creeps up on you when the credits roll. There are villainous Nazeees, daring partisans and doughty American G.I.s, but also a spiritual and emotional rawness to its harrowing action scenes and war-weary characters. Paisan ‚Äì or ‚Äòcompatriot‚Äô ‚Äì is as a powerful statement of what it means to be Italian as any film on this list.‚ÄîPhil de Semlyen

28. Umberto D. (1952)

Director: Vittorio De Sica

Some movies break your heart. Vittorio De Sica‚Äôs wound the soul. More sentimental than Bicycle Thieves, Umberto D. is the poignant face of neorealism. It‚Äôs a movie about the callousness of society, couched in the story of a poor old man and his dog. Kicked out on the street after failing to make rent, the titular pensioner (Carlo Battisti) is driven to despair, pulled back only by the loyalty to his adorable fox terrier. It is perhaps the most unvarnished film in a genre that stripped cinema to its bones, and in that way represents neorealism‚Äôs peak. The movement never produced another classic after it.‚ÄîMatthew Singer

Advertising

29. Danger: Diabolik (1968)

Director: Mario Bava

Imagine if Austin Powers was played completely straight, and about twice as psychedelic. Danger: Diabolik ‚Äì a cult classic of the Bond-aping Eurospy genre ‚Äì is what you‚Äôd get. Mario Bava‚Äôs adaption of one of Italy‚Äôs most popular comic book series, concerning the capers of the titular, costumed super-criminal and the authorities attempting to thwart him, is full of flashy cars, underground lairs, and gonzo gadgets ‚Äî like ‚Äòexhilarating gas‚Äô and an aeroplane with a trapdoor. Amid all the scantily-clad ladies, there‚Äôs also a cigar-chomping crime lord played by Thunderball villain Adolfo Celi.‚ÄîJames Balmont

Director: Federico Fellini

You could include every Federico Fellini film on this list ‚Äì easily. But if you must start somewhere, start with Amarcord, the maestro‚Äôs homage to small-town Italian life set in the 1930s, when the country was under Mussolini‚Äôs rule. Low on plot but long on humour (Fellini loved a fart joke), Amarcord is a portrait of the sentimental education of youngster Titta, as he comes of age surrounded by the eccentric characters of his town. Autobiographical in parts, but fantastical in others, it skewers the doctrines of fascist Italy while lovingly remembering the era that Fellini himself grew up in.‚ÄîAnna Bogutskaya

Advertising

31. The Tree of Wooden Clogs (1978)

Director: Ermanno Olmi

Mike Leigh describes this Palme d'Or-winning pastoral as ‚Äòextraordinary on a number of levels‚Äô. One of them is the captivating detail and authenticity of its vision of rural life. Like Clarkson‚Äôs Farm with more relatable characters, it spans a year on one Bergamo farm in the late 1890s, as crops are planted, animals slaughtered, and new generations welcomed into the ranks of its four hard-toiling families. It was filmed over four months on an old farm, with Ermanno Olmi drawing on his grandmother‚Äôs memories of her younger days as a peasant (jotted down in notebooks) to craft an soft-spoken and slow-burn tribute to life on the land.‚ÄîPhil de Semlyen

32. La Terra Trema (1948)

Director: Luchino Visconti

Neorealism‚Äôs On the Waterfront, Visconti‚Äôs rugged tale of Sicilian fishermen is a punch in the gut that leaves even other great filmmakers winded. Martin Scorsese lists it among his all-time favourites, and its ability to make you first understand, and then care about, its hard-pressed characters is timeless. It‚Äôs a deeply sad film in which poverty is depicted as an absence ‚Äì of joy, family comforts, and solidarity ‚Äì and whose mariners, constantly lowballed by wholesalers in a way that the actual fishermen who played them could probably relate to, are slowly beaten down by a rigged system.‚ÄîPhil de Semlyen

Advertising

Director: Michelangelo Antonioni

Italy‚Äôs foremost purveyor of modernist alienation, Michelangelo Antonioni is best known in the English-speaking world for 1966‚Äôs Blow Up, an enigmatic murder-mystery set in Swinging London. But his films set in bourgeois Italian society made his name, and L‚ÄôEclisse (‚ÄòThe Eclipse‚Äô) may be their pinnacle. It‚Äôs set in a bleak Rome, shorn of Via Veneto glamour. There‚Äôs the icy elegance of Monica Vitti, drifting around the city after a nasty break-up, meeting Roman stockbroker Piero (Alain Delon) and not-quite starting a new affair. Enigmatic and mood-oriented, it requires patience. But its feeling of despair, backdropped by the noise and artifice of contemporary society, is all-encompassing.‚ÄîChristina Newland

Director: Pier Paolo Pasolini

Few films are as shudderingly erotic as Pier Paolo Pasolini‚Äôs Theorem. A devilish Terence Stamp is a mysterious visitor who arrives at the front door of a bourgeois Milanese family and quickly inveigles his way into beds of everyone in the household, before suddenly vanishing again. lf Theorem has defied analysis since its controversial release in 1968, and remains ambiguous: we‚Äôll never truly know if Stamp‚Äôs visitor is a destructive or liberating force ‚Äì even Pasolini‚Äôs comments on it were contradictory. The film‚Äôs influence can be felt on everything from Tom Ripley to Saltburn, but nothing else comes close: Theorem is timeless.‚ÄîAnna Bogutskaya

Advertising

35. Big Deal on Madonna Street (1958)

Director: Mario Monicelli

Like Rififi on nitrous, this crime caper is a giddy pisstake of the stony-faced heist thrillers that were everywhere in America and France at the time. Writer-director Mario Monicelli wasn‚Äôt just a comedy master ‚Äì later, he‚Äôd make fierce political screed I Compagni (‚ÄòThe Organizer‚Äô) ‚Äì but his gift for overseeing finely-tuned slapstick courses through this very breezy, very silly classic. Vittorio Gassman, Renato Salvatori and Marcello Mastroianni are among five burglars attempting to rip off a Roman pawn shop, only to get it all horribly wrong. It was pipped to a Best Foreign Film Oscar by Jacques Tati‚Äôs Mon Oncle, which probably made sense in context.‚ÄîPhil de Semlyen

36. Accattone (1961)

Director: Pier Paolo Pasolini

Described by one critic as ‚Äòmaybe the grimmest movie I‚Äôve ever seen‚Äô, Pasolini‚Äôs depiction of the life of a Roman pimp is not a rollicking LOL-fest. Yet, in its jagged juxtaposition of the spiritual (the Bach score) with the amoral (everything else), it‚Äôs a piercing glimpse at life on the fringes of an otherwise booming society. The director rejected the term ‚Äòneorealism‚Äô for his debut film, but it‚Äôs hard not to see the grasping Accattone ‚Äì played by first-timer Franco Citti ‚Äì as desperate kin to Bicycle Thieves‚Äô dad or the fisherman in La Terra Trema. He‚Äôs one cinema‚Äôs most irredeemable characters, but for all his calculating, contemptuous treatment of his sex-worker girlfriend (Silvana Corsini), he‚Äôs still recognisably human.‚ÄîPhil de Semlyen

Advertising

37. Hands Over the City (1963)

Director: Francesco Rosi

The side of a Naples apartment block crumbles and collapses into the street, crushing a man and injuring a small boy. From that starkly dramatic opening, Francesco Rosi‚Äôs vigorous and angry drama maps out a system in which men like Rod Steiger‚Äôs corrupt politician and real estate developer, Edoardo Nottola, flourish by cutting corners and making dodgy back-room deals. Rosi‚Äôs camera never gets too close to the potential hero, a communist councilman played by real-life politician Carlo Fermariello ‚Äì mainly because his story has no heroes. Instead, Steiger, all seedy menace in the best film of his Italian phase, looms over it like the Teflon face of greed and corruption.‚ÄîPhil de Semlyen

38. The Seduction of Mimi (1972)

Director: Lina Wertm√ºller

Lina Wertm√ºller was a towering and iconoclastic figure of Italian cinema, in part because she was a woman in film at a time when the primary genre flicks of the time ‚Äì giallo horrors and poliziotteschi crime films ‚Äì were often misogynistic and male-dominated.
